title: R44587
content: The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) was established in 1967 under the U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) to investigate civil aviation accidents and other transportation incidents. In 1974, the Independent Safety Board Act made NTSB independent of DOT, allowing unbiased investigations and safety recommendations. The NTSB's main role is determining accident causes. The NTSB investigates accidents and makes safety recommendations, providing assistance to victims' families. It does not have the authority to enforce its recommendations or regulate safety practices in transportation, which falls under the jurisdiction of the DOT. The NTSB's safety recommendations and advocacy programs have influenced transportation agencies and congressional decision-making.
